titleStmt.title: Extract of Count Gollowin's answer to the said Memorial dated Mosco 5./16. May 1705
titleStmt.author: Fedor
Alekseevich
Golovin

head.title: 5 / 16 May 1705. – Extract of Count Gollowin's{{p0277}} answer to the said Memorial dated Mosco 5./16. May 1705

note.bibl: NA Kew, Russia, no. SP 91-5, f. 89v-90v. English copy.

div.p: Extract of Count Gollowin's{{p0277}} answer to the said Memorial dated Mosco 5./16. May 1705

Concerning the Exportation of goods Customfree according to the Contract, althou this was allowed by the Czars especiall grace for the produce of the Tobacco, in hopes to increase that Trade for the advantage of both dominions ; yet since so many disorders were committed by the Company{{o0137}} and their factors, as renderd the Contract null, as well by their own not importing the full quantity stipulated in the Treaty, as by the abuses of their factors and retalers, who sold Circassian Tobacco instead of English ; and that by such unwarantable practices their Treaty was entirely broke, the Czar{{p0174}} did not think convenient to make good the gace he had promisd them, for by the Treaty itself, it was not agreed, that the goods should be exported without any dutys at all, but only on paying the moderate and usuall Customs as the Envoy himself may plainly see out of the original English Contract.

What concerns the Letter of Exchange, which Mr. Goodfellow{{p1252}} gave for 20 m. Dollars, he was not constraind to it, but he did it for his free will, because several Commodities had been taken of him, as part of the Tobacco duties at very high rates, several other andvantages had been also allowed to the Company{{o0137}} and to the Consul{{p1252}} himself in particular ; as the giving of Podwodes or free carridges for the Tobacco, and such like helps as were not stipulated in the Treaty. All which might have more than made good the little advantage of this bill of Exchange ; the said bill lay also above a year and a half unpayd, and the money was taken up at great loss, and these R Dollars have been plac’d to his account instead of Russian money due for Customs at a reasonable price ; and not at an underate.

What relates to the Contract for flax ; this does not in the least concern the Company{{o0137}}, but was given to the Consul{{p1252}} himself as a particular mark of the Czars favour, to encourage him in a Commerce on the East Sea, whereof the Consul{{p1252}} gave some hopes ; as to the duty thereof, it was order’d to be taken accordingly to the usuall Customs, which were pay’d by all Merchants, and not according to the new impositions laid on that commodity. Notwithstanding which several
particular favours beyond what was agreed to in the first Traety, all has been to no purpose.
